Dalian China China Catalyst Holding Co., Ltd., Dalian, China d University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China e Division of Energy Research Resources, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, China Division of Energy Research Resources, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian China Division of Energy Research Resources, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, China f State Key Laboratory of catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, China State Key Laboratory of catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian China State Key Laboratory of catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Shenyang University of Chemical Technology, College of Chemical Engineering, Shenyang, China Shenyang University of Chemical Technology, College of Chemical Engineering Shenyang China 1 These authors contributed equally: Lei Zhu, Qiao Yuan Ethanol dehydrogenation is of great industrial significance, but remains a challenge to use non-oxidative pathways. In this paper, Mo sites in different states were carefully constructed on sulfur-doped carbon (S-C) by adjusting the thermal treatment conditions, which showed distinct performance in the direct heterogeneous dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate. Among them, Mon/S-C with fully exposed molybdenum clusters anchored by sulfur sites showed the best performance with a space-time yield (STY) of 550 gacetyl/kgcat./h and a selectivity of 92 % for the target acetyl product, which can be stable for more than 70 h. The Mo6 + species with electronic property modulated by sulfur were the active sites for ethanol dehydrogenation. The coordination-dependent catalytic performance was rationalized through possible reaction pathways, which demonstrated the evolution of active species during the reaction. Graphical Abstract Keywords Molybdenum clusters Ethanol dehydrogenation Sulfur-doped carbon Acetaldehyde Ethyl acetate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The escalating challenges of global climate change, dwindling fossil fuel reserves, and rising crude oil costs have brought energy security to the forefront of global concerns. Given the geographically concentrated distribution of finite oil reserves and their continued depletion, research into advancing alternative energy sources such as biomass has become a critical priority in modern scientific studies [1]. Ethanol, a fundamental chemical compound, is extensively utilized in the production of beverages, pharmaceuticals, biofuels, cosmetics, and dyes. Large-scale bio-ethanol production is now globally established, while ethanol synthesis from syngas and methanol has also evolved into a mature industrial process [2–5]. There is a pressing demand for further in-depth research into the downstream conversion processes of ethanol. Ethanol dehydrogenation constitutes a significant industrial procedure for the manufacture of acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate, both of which are high value-added products in fine chemical engineering and the solvent industry [6,7]. Over the past decades, numerous catalytic strategies have been investigated for the transformation of ethanol into various products including acetaldehyde, ethyl acetate, n-butanol, C6+ alcohols, 1,3-butadiene, and aromatic compounds [8–11]. Currently, there are two predominant pathways for ethanol dehydrogenation [11]: one involves the dehydrogenation in the presence of an oxidizing agent [12], and the other entails the direct dehydrogenation in an oxygen-free environment [13]. In these two reaction pathways, the direct dehydrogenation of ethanol without an oxidant aligns with the principles of green chemistry. This process achieves an atomic utilization up to 100 %, thus garnering increasing attention from researchers. Moreover, acetaldehyde serves as an intermediate material in the production of dyes, pharmaceuticals, fragrances, and pesticides [14]. Ethyl acetate stands out as an important ester, predominantly utilized as an eco-friendly solvent to substitute for the hazardous aromatic compounds, and also serving as a pivotal precursor in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, fragrances, and other chemicals [15–18]. In the past, ethanol dehydrogenation catalysts primarily focused on homogeneous systems [19], which offered superior low-temperature performance compared to heterogeneous counterparts. Moreover, adding various ligands and promoters to improve catalysts was common means of adjustment in homogeneous systems. Nevertheless, a significant issue was the difficulty in recycling these catalysts [20]. As a result, there has been a growing interest in heterogeneous systems in recent years. Heterogeneous catalytic systems exhibit enhanced thermal stability, improved recyclability, and compatibility with continuous flow reactors, rendering them particularly promising for industrial-scale implementation [19,20]. Mavrikakis and Barteau [21] discovered that the dehydrogenation of C1 and C2 alcohols over Group Ⅷ metals (such as Ni, Pd, Pt, Ru) and Group IB metals (for example Cu, Ag, Au) occurred sequentially with the order of alcohol adsorption, abstraction of the O-H bond to generate alkoxides, followed by α-H bond removal to form aldehyde intermediates[22]. However, Ouyang et al. [23] demonstrated that palladium catalysts supported on distinct substrates exhibit dispersion-dependent selectivity in ethanol dehydrogenation, providing new perspectives for designing efficient palladium-based catalysts for alcohol conversion. Furthermore, Guan et al. [24] fabricated Au nanoparticle catalysts of size-controlled on the silica support through deposition technique and found that these catalysts were highly active in the ethanol dehydrogenation. Among these catalytic systems, Cu-based catalysts have been widely studied in ethanol dehydrogenation due to their superior O–H bond activation capability and cost-effectiveness [25–29]. Although they exhibited high activity and selectivity, Cu nanoparticles are prone to aggregation into bulky Cu particles in the presence of hydrogen or water, leading to the irreversible deactivation of catalysts [23]. The sulfur-doped carbon (S-C) material with a large specific surface area and high sulfur content developed by Liang et al. [30,31] is recognized as an outstanding support material for promoting metal dispersion and utilization efficiency, due to its robust capacity to anchor and stabilize metals nanoparticles or clusters. This study was inspired by previous work from the research group[32]. By modifying post-treatment conditions, we carefully designed and prepared a molybdenum-based catalyst anchored on sulfur-doped carbon (Mo/S-C). Unexpectedly, molybdenum species with different valence states exhibited fundamentally distinct reactivity in ethanol dehydrogenation reactions. The unique coordination environment of the Mo center in the Mo/S-C catalyst was supported by comprehensive characterization techniques, such as XRD, HR-TEM, HAADF-STEM, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), etc. Remarkably, the Mon/S-C catalyst with Mo6+ clusters showed excellent performance in the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction with a space-time yield (STY) of 550 gacetyl/kgcat./h, 92 % selectivity for the target acetyl product and over 70 h operational stability in a fixed-bed reactor. Finally, the relationship between structure evolution of the Mo species and catalytic performance was established via a series of characterization. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and structure characterization of Mo/S-C The synthetic process of sulfur-doped carbon (S-C) and Mo/S-C catalysts is demonstrated in Fig. 1. S-C support was prepared by the pyrolysis of the home-made cobalt-bithiophene complexes with fumed silica as a hard template, in which S content can reach to 10.0 wt% as well as Co and Si being in trace amount (Table S1), based on inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) [31]. The Mo/S-C was prepared by incipient wet impregnation and ultrasonic dispersion method, followed by drying with the rotary evaporation at 353 K. The Mon/S-C and Mooxide/S-C catalysts were formed through thermal treatment at 823 K in a flow of H2 and argon for 2 h, respectively. Figure S1a and S1b show the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images of the Mo/S-C catalysts, where the Mon/S-C catalyst shows no Mo nanoparticles on the S-C support, while the Mooxide/S-C catalyst shows obvious big nanoparticles of molybdenum species. Furthermore, elemental mapping images obtained via energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) for the Mon/S-C catalyst demonstrated a uniform dispersion of Mo, S, and C elements throughout the catalyst structure. (Figure S2). Simultaneously, the prepared Mo/S-C catalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Figure S3). The analysis revealed that the Mon/S-C catalyst exhibited only broad diffraction peaks in the angular ranges of 20° to 30° and 40° to 50°, which are attributed to the S-C support matrix, with no discernible peak indicative the presence of metallic or oxide Mo. In contrast, the Mooxide/S-C catalyst displayed distinct and pronounced peaks at 25°, 36°, and 55°, which correspond to the characteristic diffraction patterns of molybdenum dioxide. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images reveal that nearly fully exposed clusters [33–35] are distinctly visible on the fresh Mon/S–C catalyst, with an average of 10 Mo atoms per cluster ( Fig. 2 a and b). These results indicate that fully exposed Mo clusters can be successfully obtained on S-C by trapping Mo ions with thiophene sulfur species via hydrogen reduction. In addition, the surface morphology and structural characteristics of S-C and Mo/S-C catalysts were also obtained. The N2 sorption isotherms of S-C, Mon/S-C and Mooxide/S-C catalysts show the typical IV hysteresis loop (Figure S4a), indicating the hierarchical pore of support and catalysts, consistent with the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (Figure S5). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume of S-C, Mon/S-C and Mooxide/S-C catalysts could reach 1194, 890 and 875 m2/g, as well as 2.8, 2.1 and 2.6 cm3/g, respectively. The S-C, Mon/S-C, and Mooxide/S-C catalysts all display a bimodal pore size distribution, with one peak located in the range of 5–10 nm and the second peak in the range of 20–40 nm (Figure S4b and Table S2). To investigate the electronic properties and surface elemental composition of S-C and Mo/S-C catalysts, XPS analysis was performed. As the core element and active center, the binding energies of 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spin-orbit splitting of Mo locate at of 224–240 eV for the two catalysts (Fig. 2 c). The Mo 3d5/2 peak of the Mooxide/S-C catalyst (64 %) appeared at 228.6 eV, corresponding to the standard Mo4+ species, which is consistent with the XRD results. The formation of molybdenum dioxide under an argon atmosphere may originate from the hygroscopic nature of the molybdenum pentachloride precursor. Since molybdenum pentachloride readily captures oxygen from the solvent, hydrolysis leads to molybdenum oxychloride formation as oxygen from the hydrochloric acid aqueous solution (5 wt%) replaces chlorine atoms during the preparation process. Subsequently, molybdenum oxide species was generated during the heat treatment process under inert atmosphere [36]. Surprisingly, the standard Mo6+ species with the peak at 232.8 eV dominated on Mon/S-C after H2 treatment with 61 % proportion. Due to the special anchoring and electronic effect, the fully exposed Mo clusters with Mo6+ species appeared in H2 atmosphere. Furthermore, H2-TPR analysis (Figs. S6a-6b) reveals that the reduction peak of the Mon/S-C catalyst after hydrogen reduction pretreatment shifts to a lower temperature compared to the uncalcined catalyst, suggesting partial reduction of Mo species during pretreatment. Both Mon/S-C and Mooxide/S-C catalysts exhibit reduction peaks near 720 K and 930 K. In contrast, the Mooxide/S-C catalyst displays an additional reduction peak at 596 K, indicating distinct electronic states of Mo in the two catalysts. Notably, the Cl 2p spectrum exhibits that a small amount of Cl exists on Mooxide/S-C, whereas its content reduces in considerable degrees over Mon/S-C catalyst (Figure S7) [30,37]. After reduction in hydrogen atmosphere, the content of residual chloride ion is less, accompanied by an increase in Mo dispersion. Furthermore, XPS analysis of the S 2p region demonstrates that sulfur atoms exist in two chemical states: predominantly thiophene-like sulfur (80 %) and minor sulfate species. (Fig. 2 d) [38,39]. Notably, the S 2p3/2 binding energy of thiophene sulfur in the Mon/S-C catalyst exhibits a distinct shift, directly indicating electronic interactions between Mo and S. The content of sulfur almost unchanged between the Mon/S-C catalysts and the S-C support, indicating the stability of S species under high reduction atmosphere (Tables S1 and S3). 2.2 Catalytic performance in ethanol dehydrogenation reaction The performance of the two as-prepared Mo/S-C catalysts was evaluated in the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction ( Fig. 3 a). The dehydrogenation and following coupling products including acetaldehyde (AcH) and ethyl acetate (EA) were the targets, accompanied by side reactions such as ethanol reforming and ethanol dehydration to diethyl ether. As the temperature increases from 543 K to 623 K, the total STY of acetyl products over Mon/S-C exhibited an eightfold enhancement from 132 to 1070 gacetyl/kgcat./h, while the selectivity for acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate decreased from 94 % to 84 % and the selectivity for alkanes increased (Fig. 3 b). This means that the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction on the Mon/S-C catalyst is temperature-sensitive. However, higher temperatures would cause the increase of side reaction and the instability of the catalyst. The influence of pressure on product selectivity exhibited a different trend to that of temperature. As the total pressure increases, Fig. 3 c shows that the selectivity of alkanes tends to decrease progressively, whereas the selectivity of acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate shows a continuous upward trend from 84 % to 94 %. The selectivity of ethyl acetate displayed a more rapid increase with the increase of total pressure. Because a relative higher partial pressure of ethanol facilitates the coupling of acetaldehyde and acetyl intermediates to form ethyl acetate. Interestingly, the Mon/S-C catalyst exhibited higher activity with the increase of reduction temperature. It should be ascribed that more Mo6+ clusters formed under high reduction temperature, which will be further described in Fig. 4. As shown in Fig. 3 e and Table S4, Mon/S-C exhibited the space-time yield (STY) of 550 gacetyl/kgcat./h while Mooxide/S-C only showed a much lower STY with 209 gacetyl/kgcat./h under the same reaction conditions. These results indicate that the performance of ethanol dehydrogenation on the Mo/S-C catalysts are affected by the valence state of the Mo site and its coordination environment. Mo6+ clusters demonstrated optimal dehydrogenation activity. We performed a preliminary screening of molybdenum loading and observed that the STY of the target products increased linearly with the loading amount (Figure S8). However, excessively high loading would hinder the formation of uniform clusters. Therefore, we selected a moderate molybdenum loading of 10 wt% as the primary focus for our research. Under the optimized conditions, we also conducted control experiments with Mo on different carriers and different active metals on S-C support (Fig. 3 f and g). Firstly, we tested molybdenum-based catalysts with identical loading (10 wt%) on other different carriers, such as TiC, AC, SiO2, Al2O3, and found that they all showed low ethanol dehydrogenation activity only one third of Mon/S-C (Fig. 3 f) and by comparing the catalytic performance of catalysts on different supports, it can be concluded that the S-C carrier plays a more important role in the Mon/S-C catalytic system, indicating that the construction of active Mo6+ clusters sites plays a decisive role. To further investigate the influence of active metal sites on ethanol dehydrogenation reaction, catalysts with various active metals supported on S-C were also tested. Subsequent evaluation of S-C-supported transition metals (Fe, Co, W, Ni, Cu) revealed inferior performance relative to Moₙ/S-C (Fig. 3 g), demonstrating the unique synergistic effect of the Mo/S-C catalytic system in ethanol dehydrogenation. This result suggested that the combination of molybdenum site and S-C support had a distinctive role together in the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction. Additionally, we also explored the impact of different molybdenum precursors on the ethanol dehydrogenation reaction. It was found that the Mon/S-C derived from molybdenum chloride and ammonium molybdate precursors both exhibited high activity for the reaction. This indicated that the choice of molybdenum precursor had minimal influence on the reaction activity (Entry 13 of Table S4 ,). The pretreatment conditions dominantly influenced on the performance of Mo/S-C. Subsequently, to further identify the active Mo species, it was performed a comparative study using molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) and molybdenum dioxide (MoO2). The results revealed that the STY of the target product for molybdenum trioxide was approximately 115 gacetyl/kgcat./h, whereas molybdenum dioxide only exhibited activity of 46 gacetyl/kgcat./h (Entry 14–15 of Table S4). This demonstrated that high-valent molybdenum (such as Mo6+ in MoO3) was more active for ethanol dehydrogenation, while lower-valent molybdenum (Mo4+ in MoO2) was less reactive for this reaction. In addition, the stability of the Mon/S-C catalyst was tested. Under kinetic control conditions, the Mon/S-C catalyst was stable for at least for 70 h, with a selectivity of 92 % toward the target product and a gradually stabilized STY of 550 gacetyl/kgcat./h (Fig. 3 h) [22]. Furthermore, comparative evaluation with state-of-the-art ethanol dehydrogenation catalysts (Table S5) reveals that the Moₙ/S-C system maintains superior target product selectivity and exceptional operational stability, outperforming conventional catalytic materials. 2.3 Active sites and their evolution on Mon/S-C catalyst for ethanol dehydrogenation As demonstrated previously, ethanol dehydrogenation activity exhibited a positive correlation with Moₙ/S-C reduction temperature. The Mon/S-C catalysts reduced under different temperatures were further studied using XRD and XPS characterizations (Fig. 4 and Figure S9). The Mo species on the S-C support were all in a highly dispersed station, and there were no obvious peaks representing the related Mo species in the XRD spectra regardless of the Mon/S-C catalyst was reduced from 723 to 973 K (Figure S9). The binding energy of 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spectra all spanning 224–240 eV for three different reduction temperatures (Fig. 4 a). Progressive temperature elevation from 723 to 973 K, the peak associated with the Mo4+ species almost diminished. While the Mo6+ species corresponding to the 232.9 eV peak position increased and gradually occupied a large proportion about 73 % with the raise of reduction temperature. The anomalous valence enhancement should be attributed to the strong coordination and electron-withdrawing effect of abundant thiophene-like sulfur species from Mo species for H2 treatment in H2 samples. As the reduction temperature continues to rise, the concentration of SO4 2- species gradually increases from 16 % to 33 %. Therefore, the excessive reduction temperature was not beneficial for the formation of stable Mo6+ species. The above characterization results confirm that the main active sites of the Mon/S-C catalyst are Mo6+ species. Subsequently, to deeply explore the evolution of active species, the spent Mon/S-C catalyst was thoroughly analyzed by means of HR-TEM, EDS mapping, XPS, and XRD, etc. ( Fig. 5 a-f and S5 d). According to the results of HR-TEM and EDS mapping (Fig. 5 a-c), individual nanoparticles formed on Mon/S-C after a period of reaction time. In addition, the proportion of Mo4+ species increased from 39 % of fresh catalyst to 64 % on spent catalyst. While Mo6+ species decreased from 61 % to 36 % after 70 h time on stream (Fig. 5 d). However, the distribution of S species did not change before and after reaction, indicating the stability of thiophene-like sulfur (Fig. 5 e). Fig. 5 f shows that weak characteristic peaks of molybdenum dioxide appear on the spent catalyst, indicating that part of Mo clusters gradually transform into molybdenum dioxide during the reaction, leading to a little decrease in activity. It can be concluded that the decisive factor of reactivity is the valence state and the existence form of molybdenum species. 2.4 Theoretical insights into the mechanism of ethanol dehydrogenation The ethanol dehydrogenation reaction catalyzed by Mo6+ species shares similar mechanism with other active metals [14,22,40]. After the adsorption and activation of ethanol, Mo6+ cluster can efficiently break the O-H bond to form ethoxy intermediates. Subsequently, it selectively cleaves the α-H bond to produce acetaldehyde. Nonetheless, during the reaction [22,40,41], there is a transformation of Mo6+ species into Mo4+ species due to the very strong oxophilicity of Mo6+ species. Mo6+ species would capture oxygen species from ethanol or H2O, leading to the formation of nanoparticles of molybdenum dioxide, analogous to the tendency of Cu+ species to aggregate and form larger Cu0 particles. Although Mo4+ species also has certain ability for O-H and α-H breakage [42], its reactivity was inferior to Mo6+ species. In-situ FTIR spectroscopy was employed to elucidate the surface reaction mechanism of ethanol dehydrogenation on Moₙ/S-C catalysts under varying thermal conditions. As depicted in Fig. 6 and S10, rapid intensification of the hydroxyl vibration band at 3670 cm⁻¹ upon ethanol introduction confirmed the chemisorption associated with Mo6+ sites. Simultaneously, characteristic vibrational bands emerged at specific wavenumbers: 2800–3000 cm⁻¹ (assigned to C–H stretching vibrations), 1300–1500 cm⁻¹ (attributed to C–H bending vibrations), and 1059 cm⁻¹ (corresponding to C–O stretching vibrations). These spectral features align with surface-bound ethyl species documented in prior studies. However, As shown in Figure S10, with the increase of temperature, the peak at 913 cm⁻¹ gradually intensifies, indicating that the cleavage of the O-H bond leads to proton adsorption on the sulfur atom, thereby forming the S-H bond.[43] Furthermore, A critical observation emerged at 583 K: the appearance of a diagnostic 1723 cm⁻¹ band corresponding to the CO stretching mode of AcH[44]. This signature was intensified at elevated temperatures (623 K), demonstrating thermal promotion of the dehydrogenation pathway. The evolution of spectral revealed quick ethanol conversion, correlating with the maximization of AcH signal. However, under continuous argon purging, the spectral features in the 2800–3000 cm⁻¹ region (C-H stretching vibration) diminished significantly, while the characteristic band at 1723 cm⁻¹ corresponding to the CO stretching vibration of AcH persisted, demonstrating sustained adsorption of generated acetaldehyde on catalytic active sites. To elucidate the acid-base properties of the synthesized catalyst, temperature-programmed desorption analyses of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO2 (CO2-TPD) were performed (Figure S11). The NH3-TPD spectrum (Figure S11a) exhibited a distinct desorption peak at 395.5 K, corresponding to weak acid sites attributed to Mo6+ Lewis acid centers. In contrast, the CO2-TPD profile (Figure S11b) demonstrated a broad desorption region spanning a temperature range of 450–700 K, characteristic of moderately strong basic sites originated from sulfur species within the carrier material. The co-existence of weak acid sites and moderately strong basic sites suggests the potential for acid-base synergistic effects in catalytic applications. It was further proposed a reaction mechanism for ethanol dehydrogenation over the Mon/S-C catalyst. Fig. 7 illustrates the catalytic cycle for ethanol dehydrogenation over the Mon/S-C catalyst. The process begins with the dissociative adsorption of ethanol on adjacent Mo6+-Mo6+ sites to form bridging ethoxy and Mo---H ([1] → [2]). Subsequently, the O-H bond breaks and the hydrogen atom is abstracted by the sulfur atom ([2] → [3]). Hydrogen recombination and desorption then occur ([3] → [5]), ultimately leading to the desorption of acetaldehyde ([5] → [1]). This pathway can easily proceed the catalytic cycle of ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde on Mon/S-C. In the subsequent stage, the acetaldehyde intermediate [6] is attacked by the newly adsorbed ethanol at Mo6+ sites [7] to form an ethoxy hemiacetal adsorbed on two Mo sites [8]. This intermediate then removes one H atom to form an ethyl acetate (EA) intermediate on adjacent Mo sites ([8] → [9]). Finally, after EA desorption and hydrogen release ([10] → [1]), the catalytic cycle of ethanol dehydrogenation to EA is completed. 2.5 Conclusion In conclusion, it was prepared a series of Mo/S-C catalysts with different valence and dispersion states for ethanol dehydrogenation. The molecular structures of Mo/S-C catalysts were elucidated by means of HR-TEM, HAADF-STEM, XPS and XRD characterizations. The reactivity was closely related to the state and valence of Mo species. Mon/S-C catalyst with Mo6+ clusters showed the highest catalytic activity for ethanol dehydrogenation with an STY of 550 gacetyl/kgcat./h, a selectivity of 92 % for acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate, and maintained the stable activity for more than 70 h. The emergence of molybdenum dioxide during the reaction process results in a little reduction of activity. Possible reaction mechanism and relative active species were speculated through control experiments. It is worth noting that Mo6+ species were found to have good activity for the first time in heterogeneous ethanol dehydrogenation. The results of this work will be conducive to the rational design of efficient catalysts for heterogeneous dehydrogenation of ethanol. 3 Experimental section 3.1 Chemicals and materials Molybdenum chloride (MoCl5, AR), 2,2’-bithiophene (C8H6S2, ≥98 %), cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6 H2O, AR), fumed silica (SiO2, AR), copper chloride (CuCl2, AR), nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6 H2O, AR), iron chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6 H2O, AR), cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6 H2O, AR), ammonium tungstate ((NH4)10H2(W2O7)6, AR), and ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O, AR), were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Ethanol (C2H5OH, AR), tetrahydrofuran (C4H8O, AR), sodium hydroxide (NaOH. AR) and sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98 %) were purchased from China National Pharmaceutical Group Corporation (Sinopharm). N2 (>99.9 %) was purchased from Dalian Kena Science and Technology Co., Ltd. 3.2 Catalyst preparation 3.2.1 Synthesis of S-C support The synthesis of Mo/S-C catalysts was carried out using a two-step method with some modifications according to the reference method. Synthesis of S-C support: the S-C support was synthesized by cobalt-assisted polymerization and carbonization of small organic molecules containing sulfur with SiO2 as hard template, followed by the alkaline and acid etching steps to remove the SiO2 template and cobalt, respectively. Typically, 2.0 g fumed silica, 2.0 g 2,2’-bithiophene, 1.0 g Co(NO3)2 6 H2O, and 150 mL THF were added into the 250-mL beaker successively, followed by magnetic stirring at ambient temperature for 6 h. The pink solid powder was obtained after the solution was dried under 313 K via a rotary evaporator and then ground in a mortar. Subsequently, a black solid composite was generated by carbonization under flowing argon atmosphere at 1073 K for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 K/min. Afterward, the composite was successively treated by 2.0 M NaOH at room temperature for 3 days and 0.6 M H2SO4 at 363 K for 9 h to remove the SiO2 templates and cobalt species, respectively. Meanwhile, the process of ultra-pure water washing was required after both the alkaline and acidic leaching to afford a neutral state. After being dried at 358 K overnight, the S-C support was finally yielded. 3.2.2 Synthesis of Mo/S-C catalysts The Mo/S-C catalyst was synthesized by impregnation technique as follows. Firstly, 0.1 g MoCl5 (35.12 wt% Mo) and 5 mL HCl (5 wt% in water) were added in a 25-mL beaker, followed by the addition of 5 mL ultra-pure water and then stirred to a clear precursor solution. Meanwhile, 0.5 g S-C was stirred and dispersed in 100 mL ultra-pure water. Afterward, the Mo precursor solution was added dropwise to the S-C suspension under ultrasonic condition at 283–288 K for 1 h. The resulting mixture was vigorously stirred for another 12 h, and then the water was dried at 353 K under vacuum with a rotary evaporator to produce the Mo/S-C catalyst. Finally, the desired catalysts, Mon/S-C and Mooxide/S-C, were obtained through a thermal treatment of H2 and argon for 2 h at 823 K, respectively. 3.2.2.1 Synthesis of M/S-C or Mo/S Catalysts (M = Cu/Ni/Fe/Co/W, S = AC/TiC/SiO2/Al2O3) The fabrication methodologies for additional M/S-C or Mo/S catalysts followed the approach of Mo/S-C, with replacement of metal precursors or support materials. These modifications included the synthesis of catalysts such as Cu/S-C, Ni/S-C, Fe/S-C, Co/S-C, W/S-C, Mo/AC, Mo/TiC, Mo/SiO2 and Mo/Al2O3. 3.2.3 Catalyst characterization The Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) patterns were generated utilizing Cu Kα radiation with a wavelength of 0.154 nm. The measurements were conducted at a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 40 mA, employing a PANalytical X’Pert Diffractometer for the analysis. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were gained on a JEM-2100 device instrument operated at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. HAADF-STEM images were acquired utilizing a JEM-ARM200F STEM/TEM instrument. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were assessed using a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 apparatus at a temperature of 77 K. Prior to the measurements, the samples underwent degassing under vacuum conditions at a temperature of 573 K for a duration of 5 h. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) coupled with Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy mapping (EDS mapping) was performed using a JSM-7800F instrument, operated at an accelerating voltage of 3.0 kV. The concentrations of elements were determined via Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES), employing a PerkinElmer Optima 7300 DV instrument. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were conducted utilizing a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250 Xi+ spectrometer, which was fitted with a monochromatic Al anode X-ray source. The spectra were recorded under ultrahigh vacuum conditions (below 1 × 10−9 torr) at a pass energy of 50 eV. The Mo 3d, S 2p, C 1 s, Cl 2p spectra were fitted by mixed Gaussian-Lorentzian component profiles after Shirley background subtraction. All the binding energies were calibrated to the C 1 s line at 284.8 eV as a reference. Chemical adsorption characterizations, including hydrogen temperature-programmed reaction (H2-TPR), carbon dioxide temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) and ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), were conducted on AutoChem Ⅱ 2920 from Micromeritics Instruments Co., Ltd. and AMI-300 from Zeton Altamira Instruments Co., Ltd with an on-line mass spectrometer OmniStar. All experiments were conducted using 30 mg of catalysts, with pretreatment under argon at 423 K for 1 h prior to testing. In the H2-TPR (hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction) experiments, the temperature was methodically elevated from 323 K to 1073 K. Once the catalyst was properly positioned, the temperature was rapidly increased from 323 K to 1073 K at a controlled rate of 5 K/min. This process was carried out under a 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere, with a flow rate maintained at 20 mL/min. Throughout this procedure, the resulting signals were recorded using mass spectrometry (MS) to capture the reduction profiles of the catalyst. However, in the NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD experiments, the temperature program was initiated by stabilizing the catalyst at 323 K under a He flow (20 mL/min). The temperature was subsequently ramped from 323 K to 800 K at a constant rate of 5 K/min. During the temperature-programmed desorption process, the gas atmosphere was switched to 10 % NH3/He or 10 % CO2/He (flow rate: 20 mL/min) for NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD measurements, respectively. The desorption profiles were monitored in real-time using mass spectrometry (MS) to obtain catalyst-specific desorption curves. 3.2.4 Evaluation of catalyst performance The catalytic performance of heterogeneous ethanol dehydrogenation was evaluated using a stainless steel fixed-bed flow reactor with an inner diameter of 9 mm. Typically, 0.2 g catalyst was pretreated with H2 at 823 K for 2 h under atmospheric pressure prior to the reaction. After the temperature decreased to 583 K, nitrogen at a certain pressure (3.0 MPa) controlled by a mass flow controller and liquid alcohols pumped quantitatively (0.02 mL/min) by a high-pressure liquid pump were introduced into the reactor simultaneously before vaporized with a preheater at 423 K. The specific reaction conditions were attached with corresponding data. The liquid products condensed by a cold trap (278 K) were collected and analyzed offline by an Agilent 7890 A gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a DB-WAX capillary column and an FID detector. Meanwhile, all the incondensable gases were analyzed online using a TCD detector with a Porapak-Q column. The products were identified against pure samples by gas chromatograph-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). Taking ethanol substrate as an example, the alcohols conversion, products selectivity and carbon balance were calculated based on carbon moles combined the liquid and gas products, which were quantified by means of the internal standard method and normalization method, respectively. The detail equations are shown in the following: Conv EtOH = n EtOHin − n EtOHout n EtOHin × 100 % Sel i = N i × n i ∑ N i × n i × 100 % STY acetyl = n AcH + n EtOAc m cat . × t Where Conv EtOH is the conversion of ethanol. Sel i represents the selectivity of product i including C2H5OC2H5 (ether), C2H4, C2H6, CH3CHO (AcH), CH3COOCH2CH3 (EA). N i means the number of carbon atoms of product i and n i denotes the moles of product i. STY acetyl is the space time yield of acetyl with the unit of gacetyl/(kgcat.·h). m cat. and t stand for the mass of catalyst and interval time of sampling. coredata.dc:description: Ethanol dehydrogenation is of great industrial significance, but remains a challenge to use non-oxidative pathways. In this paper, Mo sites in different states were carefully constructed on sulfur-doped carbon (S-C) by adjusting the thermal treatment conditions, which showed distinct performance in the direct heterogeneous dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate. Among them, Mon/S-C with fully exposed molybdenum clusters anchored by sulfur sites showed the best performance with a space-time yield (STY) of 550 gacetyl/kgcat./h and a selectivity of 92 % for the target acetyl product, which can be stable for more than 70 h. The Mo6 + species with electronic property modulated by sulfur were the active sites for ethanol dehydrogenation. The coordination-dependent catalytic performance was rationalized through possible reaction pathways, which demonstrated the evolution of active species during the reaction.
